Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Linked geomorphic-ecological disturbance response as a driver of alterations in aquatic-to-terrestrial energy flux: consequences of dam removal on a mid-size river
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dam removal provides an excellent opportunity to study how rivers respond to environmental disturbance. Despite the increasing popularity of dam removal as a river restoration approach, many ecosystem responses remain largely unknown. This RAPID project will investigate the influences of dam removal on short-term (<1.5 years) responses in channel geomorphology and aquatic- to-terrestrial flows of carbon and energy. To do this, linked aquatic-terrestrial food webs will be studied in a mid-size river in Columbus, OH, where a large, lowhead dam was recently removed. The study team is well positioned to conduct this research, having collected data in the study system three years prior to dam removal. The geomorphic influence of dam removal on aquatic-terrestrial connections, food webs, and riparian ecosystem communities represents novel research that builds on documented community shifts in fish and other aquatic biota following dam removal. The intellectual merit of the proposed work lies in establishing how the disturbance of dam removal drives linked river-riparian responses.

By advancing our understanding of the short-term effects of the disturbance of dam removal on ecosystem function, this study will contribute to efforts to maintain and/or restore rivers in human-dominated environments. The project includes involvement of undergraduate and graduate students and inclusion of study findings in The Ohio State University (OSU) coursework. Additionally, local high school students not traditionally exposed to research and STEM activities will be engaged in project research activities through an existing partnership with OSU's Upward Bound program. The study team will also deliver a dam-removal workshop run out of OSU's Shiermeier Olentangy River Wetland Research Park. This workshop will address ecological consequences of dam removal and will involve the public, local watershed groups, city planners, and agency personnel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dam removal provides an excellent opportunity to study how rivers respond to environmental disturbance. However, despite dam removal’s increasing popularity as a river restoration approach, many ecosystem responses remain largely unknown. This project investigated the influences of dam removal on responses of channel geomorphology and aquatic-to-terrestrial flows of carbon and energy via emergent aquatic insects 2-3 years following dam removal. Benthic invertebrate and fish assemblages were also surveyed. Building on 3 years of data taken prior to dam removal, coordinated hydrogeomorphic and ecological sampling was conducted at approximately 4-month intervals following removal of a large, lowhead dam in a mid-size river flowing through Columbus, Ohio. The geomorphic influence of dam removal on the ecological connections between aquatic and terrestrial systems represents novel research due to the unusually high level of system integration. The intellectual merit of the proposed work lies in establishing how the disturbance of dam removal drives (1) aquatic community shifts in a highly-modified, urban landscape and (2) linked river-riparian responses within a hydrogeomorphic context.

Preliminary findings suggest subtle geomorphic adjustment to dam removal in this system characterized by moderate stability in size and position of larger river bed features including pools and riffles and limited change in riverbed sediment size. Sediments impounded behind the removed dam have likely been mobilized downstream, however, there appears to be limited influence on the grainsize distribution of upstream and downstream reaches or on larger bedform features. For example, the proportion of fine grains (<2 mm) decreased during the first year following dam removal upstream of the removed dam but recovered in the second year. In addition, the river appears to be characterized by some degree of background variability as evidenced by changes in grain size distribution in control reaches not affected by dam removal activities.

Data processing and analysis are underway for emergent aquatic insects, riparian spiders and ants, and stable isotope analysis to quantify carbon and energy flux from aquatic to terrestrial environments. However, significant changes in fish assemblages were observed. Upstream assemblage composition shifted between before and after dam removal time periods. Assemblage shifts were also significant between years 1 and 2 both upstream and downstream of dam removal. Notably, in the first year post-dam removal, reductions in fish species richness and diversity in upstream reaches were accompanied by the loss of large-bodied omnivorous species. In the second year, an increase in species diversity was observed upstream of the removed dam at a restored reach, which was accompanied by a shift from larger-bodied omnivores and carnivores to insectivores. Given the limited geomorphic response, we attribute these observations to changes in water chemistry and increased access to benthic habitat. Results from coordinated surveys of geomorphology, water-chemistry, and biotic assemblages at a series of seven riffles (6 of which developed following dam removal) also support this conclusion, where significant differences in sediment size distributions, water depth, and streamflow velocities between study riffles and over time were documented, but further analysis indicated that that once riffles were established, chemical water-quality variables were generally more strongly related to benthic macroinvertebrates and fish. Thus, although initial results suggest that lowhead dam removal may act as a pulse disturbance in river systems, identifying the precise mechanisms will require further data analysis.
